data.title: Michael Learned
data.meta_description: In her two-and-a-half-hour interview, Michael Learned speaks of her early life and theatrical training. She recalls early roles on Canadian television and acting on stage in San Francisco in a production of Private Lives directed by Francis Ford Coppola. She discusses her iconic role of "Olivia Walton" on the classic CBS series The Waltons, recalling how she replaced Patricia Neal who'd earlier played the role. She describes her chemistry with Ralph Waite who played "John Walton," her husband on the show. Learned outlines the various changes over the run of the show, including the declining health of Ellen Corby ("Grandma Walton"), the death of Will Geer ("Grandpa Walton"), and the departure of Richard Thomas ("John-Boy"). She speaks of leaving The Waltons and her subsequent return to television in the short-lived series Nurse. She talks about numerous guest-starring roles, made-for-television movie roles, and roles she played on various daytime dramas. Adrienne Faillace conducted the interview on November 11, 2014 in Beverly Hills, CA.
data.text:
Actress

The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences Foundation Presents

02:26

Tab

About

About this interview

In her two-and-a-half-hour interview, Michael Learned speaks of her early life and theatrical training. She recalls early roles on Canadian television and acting on stage in San Francisco in a production of Private Lives directed by Francis Ford Coppola. She discusses her iconic role of "Olivia Walton" on the classic CBS series The Waltons, recalling how she replaced Patricia Neal who'd earlier played the role. She describes her chemistry with Ralph Waite who played "John Walton," her husband on the show. Learned outlines the various changes over the run of the show, including the declining health of Ellen Corby ("Grandma Walton"), the death of Will Geer ("Grandpa Walton"), and the departure of Richard Thomas ("John-Boy"). She speaks of leaving The Waltons and her subsequent return to television in the short-lived series Nurse. She talks about numerous guest-starring roles, made-for-television movie roles, and roles she played on various daytime dramas. Adrienne Faillace conducted the interview on November 11, 2014 in Beverly Hills, CA.

All views expressed by interviewees are theirs alone and not necessarily those of the Television Academy.

"The legacy of The Waltons is that it lives on in the hearts of people who responded to the message of love and forgiveness and strength. Those are good messages."

Full Interview

Play Full Interview

Chapter 1

On her early life and influences; on her early interest in performing; on her early memories of television and movies

On becoming an actress; on appearing on Canadian television; on appearing in the play "Private Lives"

On being cast as "Olivia Walton" on The Waltons; on the character of "Olivia Walton" on The Waltons; on the chemistry with the children on The Waltons

On the premise and tone of The Waltons; on the production of The Waltons; on working with show creator Earl Hamner, Jr.

Chapter 2

On working with the producers of The Waltons; on The Waltons' catchphrases and the dinner table scenes

On the cast of The Waltons; on the departure of Richard Thomas from The Waltons; on the death of Will Geer

On doing publicity for The Waltons and the popularity of the show; on leaving The Waltons; on her Emmy nominations and wins for the show; on the legacy of The Waltons

On starring on Nurse; on guest-starring on Scrubs; on appearing in various made-for-television movies and guest-starring on various series including Gunsmoke

Chapter 3

On appearing on daytime dramas; on her stage work; on then-current projects

On what she likes about acting; on how things have changed for actresses since she started; on how she'd like to be remembered and advice to aspiring actors
